proper noun.description: A battleship whose crew mutinied during the Russian Revolution of 1905 when in the Black Sea, bombarding Odessa before seeking asylum in Romania. The incident persuaded the tsar to agree to a measure of reform.

adjective.description: Having a false or deceptive appearance, especially one presented for the purpose of propaganda.
examples: a Potemkin news network, set up only to give the appearance of a free press

origin: 1930s: from Grigori Aleksandrovich Potyomkin (often transliterated Potemkin), a favorite of Empress Catherine II of Russia, who reputedly gave the order for sham villages to be built for the empress's tour of the Crimea in 1787.
